scene.dialogue: Attorneys, let's hear your opening arguments.

Good morning members of the Jury, Judge, and all of you with us today. I am Emile Proofinder, representing the plaintiff, Suzy Snoozer. Ms. Snoozer awoke late one summer morning to find her birds missing that she left in their cage outside overnight for air.
We will prove to you today that her neighbor, Ms. Felina Early, was negligent in allowing her cats to attack and kill Ms. Snoozer's birds.

dialogue.note: Ms. Snoozer loved her birds.

scene.dialogue: Ms. Snoozer is seeking compensation for the loss of her beloved birds and her pain and suffering.
Judge, Jury, and respected citizens-good morning. I am Bobby Refuter, today representing Ms. Felina Early.
Today I will show you that the plaintiff lacks the evidence to prove Ms. Early is liable for the loss of Ms. Snoozer's birds.
The loss of her birds is unfortunate. However, falsely placing blame and forcing compensation will not replace the birds.
Plaintiff, choose a witness to examine.
Plaintiff, you may begin your direct examination.
Please state your name and relationship to the defendant.
My name is Amy Anticattus. I have been Ms. Snoozer's and Ms. Early's neighbor for 11 years.
Please tell us what you witnessed.
Well, that morning I woke up to the most panicked screams! I jumped out of bed and rushed outside. I saw Ms. Snoozer on her front porch, staring at the birdcage and clearly upset.

dialogue.note: The cat was seen nearby with a yellow feather on it right after the birds went missing.

scene.dialogue: I could see the door was open and yellow feathers were everywhere. The birds were gone.
Did you see anything else?
Yes! I looked around for the birds and saw Ms. Early's cat sneaking around the side of Ms. Snoozer's garage. It had a yellow feather clinging to its back.
Thank you Ms. Anticattus. No more questions, your Honor.
The defense may now cross-examine the witness.
Ms. Anticattus, you said you saw Ms. Early's cat sneaking around the garage. How do you know it was her cat?
The cat is very distinctive. It has a broad face with unique markings. I would know it anywhere.

dialogue.note: The cat is always lurking on her property and near the birdcage.

scene.dialogue: In addition, it's always sneaking around Ms. Snoozer's garage. It seems to be the cat's favorite hangout.

dialogue.note: The location of the cat and feather at the time is a coincidence.

scene.dialogue: So then, it is possibly just a coincidence the cat was nearby, right, if it hangs around there often?
But the feather-there was a yellow feather on it! I have seen the cat often brushing against the cage before Ms. Snoozer awakes.
It is always trying to figure out how to get in! I shooed it away myself many times!

dialogue.note: Ms. Snoozer failed to protect her birds, though she knew about the threat.

scene.dialogue: So Ms. Snoozer knew about the threat but failed to protect her birds--
No, no, you misunderstand!
Thank you Ms. Anticattus. No more questions, your Honor.
...(typing)...
Plaintiff, you may examine the witness.
Please state your name and relationship to the defendant.

dialogue.note: People made several complaints about the cat's behavior to animal control

scene.dialogue: Animus Arresta, chief animal control officer for the county. I have visited Ms. Early's home several times, responding to complaints of her wandering cat.
Who made the complaints and why, Mr. Arresta?
Well, I can't tell you who made the complaints and still keep my job. I can say, though, that the cat is a menace.

dialogue.note: The cat attacks wildlife.

scene.dialogue: It roams free outside each morning. It snarls at children, attacks wildlife, and prowls on others' property.
So the cat has a history of showing aggression?
Definitely. I once responded to a call about a dead mouse on a doorstep. The family didn't own a cat, but Ms. Early's cat is often in their yard.
I have reminded Ms. Early often that cats, just like dogs, must be on a leash by law when outdoors, but well...
Thank you Mr. Arresta. No more questions, your Honor.
Defense, you may now cross-examine the witness.
Mr. Arresta, in your job as an animal control officer, you know much about animals' nature, do you not?
I absolutely do. I began my career studying to be a veterinarian, but a case of cat scratch fever put an end to that goal.
So it would be perfectly natural for a cat to go after squirrels, mice, and birds, would it not?
Of course, and that's why we have animal control laws, to prevent this kind of heartbreak.
Then Ms. Snoozer should also know, as a bird owner, to protect her birds from any known menace, should she not?

dialogue.note: Ms. Early fails to control her aggressive cat.

scene.dialogue: Isn't she responsible for the control of her own animals?
Well yes, but, I think you're twisting my words!
Thank you Mr. Arresta. No more questions, your Honor.
...(typing)...
(instructing jury to listen fairly to all the evidence)
The jurors are making notes. Are you?
Defense, call your next witness.
Please state your name and relationship to the defendant.
Hello, my name is Tayme Dibeast. I am an animal trainer. I helped Felina Early tame her cat.

dialogue.note: Ms. Early loves animals. She rescued her cat from a shelter.

scene.dialogue: She rescued it from the animal shelter where I volunteer. It was a wild cat.
So is it safe to say that Ms. Snoozer is a lover of all animals?
She wouldn't put her own cat or others' animals in danger on purpose, correct?
Oh, absolutely! Her cat is in excellent health. Ms. Early was very enthusiastic about the training and practiced often.
She only lets the cat outside in the early mornings, before the neighbors are out.
Would this cat be likely to have attacked Ms. Snoozer's birds?

dialogue.type: Ms. Early supervises her cat while outside.

scene.dialogue: Absolutely not, the cat knows to leave other pets alone. Besides, Ms. Early supervises her cat while it is outside.
Thank you Ms. Dibeast. No more questions, your Honor.
Plaintiff, you may now cross-examine the witness.
Ms. Dibeast, you said you are an animal trainer. Could you teach an animal, say a cat, to open doors or cages?
Hmm, it is possible if you had the right kind of handle. However, I did not teach Ms. Early's cat to do that.
Yet you said Ms. Early was "very enthusiastic" about the trainings. Might she have extended her cat's tricks on her own?
Again, it's possible, but Ms. Early supervises her cat. She lets it capture the occasional mouse that gets in her garden, just like any normal cat.
However, it's not unlocking the gate or anything.

dialogue.note: Ms. Early could have taught her cat to open the cage, or done it herself.

scene.dialogue: Oh, Ms. Early is annoyed by some animals like singing canaries? Is it possible she opened the canaries' cage herself?
No, that is not the point--
Thank you Ms. Dibeast. No more questions, your Honor.
Once all of the witnesses have testified, we'll hear the closing arguments.
Please state your name and relationship to the defendant.
Yes, of course. I am Pax Plantis, Felina Early's friend and lawn maintenance man.
I do yard work for her every Tuesday morning, then we go to breakfast.
What can you tell me about Ms. Early, Ms. Snoozer, and their pets?
Every Tuesday the birds are outside singing when I show up. Ms. Snoozer gets them when I start working.

dialogue.note: Ms. Early is friendly and responsible.

scene.dialogue: My tools must wake her up. Ms. Early is always outside to greet me with her cat.
How does Ms. Snoozer act when she retrieves the birds?
She is angry. She gives dirty looks to Felina, the cat, and me.
I think the noise irritates her and her birds, though I arrive at a decent hour.
She is always in her robe and the birds are plucking their feathers. This is a sign that the birds are feeling stress.
Thank you Mr. Plantis. No more questions, your Honor.
Plaintiff, you may now cross-examine the witness.
Mr. Plantis, you have been Ms. Early's friend for years. How does she feel about Ms. Snoozer?

dialogue.note: Ms. Snoozer is irritable toward her neighbor and the cat.

scene.dialogue: Well, she does not understand why Ms. Snoozer is so irritable.

dialogue.note: Ms. Early lets the cat out when neighbors are asleep.

scene.dialogue: She only puts her cat out when Ms. Snoozer is sleeping, even though the canaries keep her up all night with their singing.
Hmm, So Ms. Early really doesn't like the canaries, does she?

dialogue.note: Ms. Early felt irritated by the singing and lack of sleep.

scene.dialogue: Who would if you couldn't get any sleep? Honestly...
So perhaps she did let the cat attack Ms. Snoozer's innocent birds, to get some sleep?
I don't think Felina would--
Thank you Mr. Plantis. No more questions, your Honor.
Once all of the witnesses have testified, we'll hear the closing arguments.
Members of the jury, you have heard the facts for yourself. Ms. Early is clearly responsible for the untimely loss of Ms. Snoozer's birds.

dialogue.note: She trained her cat and let it out to release extra energy.

scene.dialogue: She did not like them, trained her cat to attack animals that bothered her, and let her cat roam outside in the mornings.
Deliver justice by awarding compensation to Ms. Snoozer.
Members of the jury, the plaintiff has failed to prove Ms. Early is responsible for the loss of the birds.
She clearly respects her neighbors, even those who are not respectful. She cares for her cat and supervises it well.
Ms. Snoozer's loss, though unfortunate, is due to her own failure to supervise her birds.
Members of the jury, you have heard both sides of this case.
Your community depends on you to consider the evidence fairly and make a wise decision. Please keep these points in mind:
You must follow the law. The question here is whether Ms. Felina Early is responsible for the loss of Ms. Snoozer's birds.
You must determine this based on the evidence available, not any assumptions you may make.
Do not make a decision based on feeling sorry or angry with anyone involved in the case, including the attorneys.
Your feelings about anyone in this room should not affect your decision.
Your decision as a jury must be unanimous. Each juror must agree to the same verdict.
Jury, you are excused. Please review the facts of the case.

vote.type: Ms. Early is liable for the loss of Ms. Snoozer's canaries
Ms. Early is not liable for the loss of Ms. Snoozer's canaries

statement.type: Ms. Early is liable. She obviously hates Ms. Snoozer and birds.
Ms. Early acknowledges her cat attacked the birds. Paying Ms. Snoozer is the very least she can do to help!
Ms. Early is liable because she has failed to control her animal, as required by law. She ignored warnings.
Ms. Early is not liable because Ms. Snoozer allowed her birds to roam freely. They simply flew away.
Ms. Early should not be liable. We have no concrete proof that her cat attacked the birds.
Ms. Early is a victim here. Attorney Proofinder was very mean to her and so it is wrong to hold her liable.

scene.dialogue: We, the jury, find the defendant, Felina Early, liable to the plaintiff, Suzy Snoozer, for compensation of personal pain and damages due to negligence, as charged in the complaint.
(The judge orders Ms. Snoozer to pay Ms. Early $2000 within 60 days.)
(The judge then thanks the jury and lawyers and raps his gavel on the desk.)
(Everyone rises, and the judge leaves the courtroom. The bailiff announces the end of the court session. )
We, the jury, find the defendant, Felina Early, not liable to the plaintiff, Suzy Snoozer, for compensation of personal pain and damages due to negligence, as charged in the complaint.
(The judge orders Ms. Snoozer to pay Ms. Early $2000 within 60 days.)
(The judge then thanks the jury and lawyers and raps his gavel on the desk.)
(Everyone rises, and the judge leaves the courtroom. The bailiff announces the end of the court session. )
Thank you for fulfilling your civic duty as a juror in this civil suit. You may try the case again to practice your skills.
If you have not yet served on the criminal case, please report for duty now.
Good morning members of the Jury, Judge, and all of you with us today. I am Jesse Jailem, representing our government and the laws that protect respectful citizens like you.

Today I will prove to you that the defendant is guilty beyond a reasonable doubt. He broke several laws by robbing a video game store. The laws he broke are destruction of property, unlawful entry, and robbery.
Police arrested this young man, Justin B. Goode, the day after the incident. He plead not guilty at his arraignment. Despite the evidence against him, he refused the plea bargain offered.
Judge, Jury, respected citizens--good morning. I am Orrie Defendorr, today representing Justin B. Goode.
Attorney Jailem has the burden of proof, meaning that Mr. Goode is innocent until proven guilty with facts and evidence.
Today I will show you that the prosecution lacks the evidence necessary to prove Mr. Goode is guilty of breaking any law beyond a reasonable doubt.
He is a respectful citizen just like you. He rightly plead not guilty and refused a plea bargain. You should find him not guilty of these charges.
Prosecutor, choose a witness to examine.
Please state your name and relationship to the defendant.
My name is Runnuh Bizz. I own the video game store that was broken into and robbed.
Justin comes in the store all the time. The day before the break in, he yelled at me.
Please tell us about the break in and the robbery.
My alarm company called at 2am to tell me the alarms were going off. I called the police and went to the shop.
The front window was in pieces and all the game systems were gone. Glass was everywhere. I made a police report and listed what was missing.
Please tell us what was missing.
I had 10 of the hot new 4D systems and 8 pre-owned systems on the shelves that are missing now.
Justin had been drooling over the 4D for weeks, begging for a discount.
He told me he was trying to save money for it. The last time he said this was about a week before the argument and break-in.
Thank you Ms. Bizz. No more questions, your Honor.
The defense may now cross-examine the witness.

dialogue.note: He had an argument with the shop owner the day before.

scene.dialogue: Ms. Bizz, you said you and Mr. Goode had an argument. Please tell us about it.
Well, I sell new and pre-owned video games and systems. Justin wanted to sell me a game that was old.
He was angry and called me names because I would not buy it. I know I could not have sold it again. I have to make a profit.
Is Mr. Goode the only customer that was ever angry in your store?
Well, no. Sometimes people fail to read store policy before trying to sell their items. When I will not buy the items, the people are confused and upset.
I usually am able to settle the situation though.
So Mr. Goode would not be the only person in town angry enough to get revenge, right?
I, well no, I know it was him!
Thank you Ms. Bizz. No more questions, your Honor.
...(typing)...
Prosecutor, you may examine the witness.
Please state your name and relationship to the defendant.
Suss Pihshawn, Chief of Police.
What did you discover at the scene of the crime?
Ms. Bizz has video monitoring.

dialogue.note: Justin B. Goode's image appears in the security video at time of robbery.

scene.dialogue: Mr. Goode is all over it, from smashing the windows to taking out the game systems to leaving before we arrived.
Did you find anything else?

dialogue.note: His fingerprints were near the door and counter.

scene.dialogue: Yes, we found fingerprints on the door and counter matching Mr. Goode's fingerprints.
Thank you Chief Pihshawn. No more questions, your Honor.
Defense, you may now cross-examine the witness.
Chief Pihshawn, in your investigation, did you find Mr. Goode's fingerprints in the areas around the smashed window or missing game systems?
Well no, but along with the video and the altercation the day before, we had enough to arrest him.
Did you use face recognition software to identify him in the video?

dialogue.note: The police could not confirm his image in the security video.

scene.dialogue: No, but we did try. The video never shows his whole face at once. He had his hoodie on over his head as well.

dialogue.note: The fingerprints make sense where they were as he recently visited the store.

scene.dialogue: So you identified Mr. Goode based on fingerprints that should have been there from his visit anyway.
In addition, because of Ms. Bizz's story you decided he was in the video though the image was not clear. That sounds like a poor investigation to me.
No sir, my officers were very--
Thank you Chief Pihshawn. No more questions, your Honor.
...(typing)...
(instructing jury to listen fairly to all the evidence)
The jurors are making notes. Are you?
Defense, call your next witness.
Please state your name and relationship to the defendant.
Hello, my name is Tech Rool, teacher at Gaming Senior Academy.
Justin is in my programming class.
What kind of a student is Mr. Goode?
He's a wonderful student! Average grades, but he has incredible talent.

dialogue.note: He is a very talented and kind student, eager to help others.

scene.dialogue: He often assists other students with their projects.
Do you think Justin could have robbed this store?

dialogue.note: He was saving money for a game system.

scene.dialogue: No, of course he would not. He was trying to save money for the new game system.
He respects my class rules and the other students. I cannot imagine him breaking the law.
Thank you Mr. Rool. No more questions, your Honor.
The prosecution may now cross-examine the witness.
Mr. Rool, you said Mr. Goode has 'average' grades. Why would that be if he were so talented?
He often forgets to turn in paperwork or it is incomplete. He much prefers the hands-on programming work we do most days.
So he's talented, but not a hard worker.
Well, he works hard on the tasks he enjoys, just like most of my students. That does not make him a criminal.
It does mean he might get too impatient saving money for a game system.
He loves gaming so much he could get desperate enough to steal, right?
That's unfair--and not what I meant!
Thank you Mr. Rool. No more questions, your Honor.
...(typing)...
Prosecutor, you may examine the witness.
Please state your name and relationship to the defendant.
Yes, of course. I am Vet Gaimer, Justin B. Goode's friend and neighbor.
I have known him and his family for years. We sometimes challenge each other in games.
We have our systems wirelessly connected. It's awesome.
Were you home the night of the robbery? What can you tell us about it?

dialogue.note: No one can confirm his location at the time of robbery.

scene.dialogue: I was up, playing games of course, and Justin signed off around 11pm. He must have gone to bed. I did not hear any cars all night.

dialogue.note: He was in bed at the time of the robbery and up early the next morning.

scene.dialogue: He was up early mowing the lawn the next day and putting out huge garbage bags of yard debris.

dialogue.note: He was saving money by doing yard work for his parents.

scene.dialogue: His parents give him allowance for working on the yard.
What did he tell you about the incident with Ms. Buzz?

dialogue.note: He was saving for a new game system and the saving was not going well.

scene.dialogue: Oh, he was sorry for it. He was having a bad day because he had to spend some of his savings to fix his computer.

dialogue.note: Other people have had arguments with the shop owner as well. Besides, he planned to apologize.

scene.dialogue: Justin said he would go back in a couple days and apologize. But then, well, he was arrested...
Thank you Mr. Gaimer. No more questions, your Honor.
The prosecution may now cross-examine the witness.
Mr. Gaimer, you have been Mr. Goode's friend for years. Is he involved in any activities or work outside school?

dialogue.note: He does not work nor is he involved in school activities.

scene.dialogue: No, he was hoping to get a job at Ms. Bizz's store but she had no openings. However, he is working on his own video game while teaching himself advanced programming skills.
Hmm, so Mr. Goode has no extra activities or responsibilities, other than the yard, apparently. Perhaps he thought he would make some money by selling stolen game systems?
What?! No, I mean, I would have seen him if he had stolen all those game systems. The criminal would have been busy the next day trying to get rid of them quickly.
You have a good point there, Mr. Gaimer. Perhaps that idea comes from experience. Maybe you bought one of the stolen systems.
I bet you helped him bag up the packaging into those large yard waste bags.
That's ridiculous!
Thank you Mr. Gaimer. No more questions, your Honor.
...(typing)...
(instructing jury to listen fairly to all the evidence)
The jurors are making notes. Are you?
Once all of the witnesses have testified, we'll hear the closing arguments.
Members of the jury, you have heard the facts for yourself. Mr. Goode clearly had the motive and the means to break in and rob Ms. Bizz's store.
He wanted revenge and he wanted that new game system desperately.

dialogue.note: He is a lazy student, prone to unlawful action to get what he wants.

scene.dialogue: His grades in school show he is willing to take the lazy route to meeting goals--like stealing instead of working hard and saving money.
Members of the jury, the prosecution has failed to prove Mr. Goode broke the law. The evidence is weak and easily explained.
Justin B. Goode is a law-abiding young citizen, working hard to achieve his future goals in computer programming and gaming.
Recognize that even a sliver of doubt about his guilt, and there is plenty of doubt here, means you cannot convict him. He is not guilty beyond a reasonable doubt, as required by law.
Members of the jury, you have heard both sides of this case.
Your community depends on you to consider the evidence fairly and make a wise decision. Please keep these points in mind:
You must follow the law. The question here is whether Justin B. Goode broke the laws against destruction of property, unlawful entry, and robbery.
You must determine this based on the evidence available, not any assumptions you may make.
Do not make a decision based feeling sorry or angry with anyone involved in the case, including the attorneys.
Your feelings about anyone in this room should not affect your decision.
Your decision as a jury must be unanimous. Each juror must agree to the same verdict.
Jury, you are excused. Please review the facts of the case.

vote.type: Justin B. Goode is guilty of the following charges: destruction of property, unlawful entry, and robbery.
Justin B. Goode is not guilty of the following charges: destruction of property, unlawful entry, and robbery.

statement.type: Justin B. Goode is guilty. Anyone who doesn't bother to join an afterschool club or get a job is a waste.
Justin B. Goode is guilty because the game systems' packaging was in the yard waste bags.
Justin B. Goode is guilty because we have his image on video and fingerprints at the scene of the crime.
Justin B. Goode is not guilty. He sent an apology email to the storeowner. Some other angry customer robbed it.
Justin B. Goode is not guilty because we lack enough evidence to place him at the store at the right time.
Justin B. Goode is a victim here. Attorney Stater twisted the words of the defense witnesses.

scene.dialogue: We, the jury, find the defendant, Justin B. Goode, guilty of the charges of destruction of property, unlawful entry, and robbery as charged.
(The judge orders Mr. Goode to one year of jail followed by five years of probation.)
(The judge then thanks the jury and lawyers and raps his gavel on the desk.)
(Everyone rises, and the judge leaves the courtroom. The bailiff announces the end of the court session. )
We, the jury, find the defendant, Justin B. Goode, not guilty of the charges of destruction of property, unlawful entry, and robbery as charged.
(The judge then thanks the jury and lawyers and raps his gavel on the desk.)
(Everyone rises, and the judge leaves the courtroom. The bailiff announces the end of the court session. )
Justice is served! Thank you for fulfilling your civic duty as a juror in this criminal case. You may try the case again to practice your skills.
If you have not yet served on the civil case, please report for duty now.
